content.description:
This is the second slab problem on the downhill side of the boulder. There's a longer crux sequence and the movement is pretty good. Start with the left hand on a decent slopey pinch and the right hand on a slopey edge that has experienced some breakage.

Downclimb the 5.11 tips crack mantle and drop off.
content.location: Middle of the slab on the downhill side of the boulder.

content.description:
This is the leftmost of two (or three?) problems that climb the tall slab face on the downhill side of the boulder. Â This one starts with the hands matched on a slopey rail and a high right foot. Throw for the decent crimp (crux) and then move up to the good edge. From here it's a relatively easy topout.

Downclimb the 5.11 tips mantle and drop off.
content.location: The problem is on the west face of the boulder just around the corner from the 5.11 tips crack. There are some bushes crowding the start a bit.

content.description:
This problem climbs the Northeast corner of the boulder, starting on delicate slab moves that are used to move left and up to jugs about 9 feet off the ground. Finish with long moves off the jugs to slopers and a mantle finish. Look for a better-than-expected low micro sidepull for the right hand to get started.

Downclimb the 5.11 tips mantle and drop off.
content.location: Northeast corner of the boulder, to the left of the 5.11 tips crack. Starts on good feet and almost non-existant hand holds.

content.description:
This boulder problem climbs the East face of the boulder, next to the Live Oak tree. It actually has some really nice movement and holds, including positive crimps down low and slopers on the arete up high. Start with the left facing crimps and good feet, as far right as you can, and then climb up and left to the arete before topping out. Be aware that it is possible to have an awkward or dangerous fall with the tree right there.

Downclimb the mantle on the 5.11 tips crack and drop off.
content.location: East face of the boulder next to the live oak tree.

content.description:
A unique problem that unfortunately looks better than it climbs. Tips jams and balancy footwork down low are followed by a burly mantle on the slopey ledge up high. The climb can be started with good sidepulls and pinches low to the ground or you can start standing for a slightly easier and shorter effort.

Down climb by reversing the mantle and dropping off.
